clinical_study.brief_title: Nebulized Beclometasone Dipropionate Improves Nasal Patency in Children With Allergic Rhinitis
clinical_study.official_title: Nebulized Beclometasone Dipropionate Improves Nasal Patency in Children With Allergic Rhinitis
clinical_study.source: Istituto di Biomedicina e Immunologia Molecolare Alberto Monroy

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to examine in children with persistent AR the effect of the topically applied beclomethasone in comparison with cetirizine on nasal patency evaluated by acoustic rhinometry and subjective nasal symptoms.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Nasal patency evaluated by acoustic rhinometry.
primary_outcome.description: The main objective is to assess the increase of nasal patency in children aged 6-16 with perennial allergic rhinitis (PAR), treated with Beclometasone nasal spray 100 µg/die for 21 days.

secondary_outcome.measure: Efficacy of Beclometasone nasal spray on subjective nasal symptoms
secondary_outcome.description: The secondary objective is to measure the impact of Beclometasone nasal spray 100 µg on subjective nasal symptoms, in children aged 6-16 with perennial allergic rhinitis (PAR), assessed by T4SS Questionnaire(Total 4 Symptoms Score).

arm_group.description: Standard dose (400 µg/daily as 100 µg 1 spray nos bid) of Nasal Beclomethasone Dipropionate for 21 days.
For Children < 12 years old 10 drops die (5 mg die) for 21 days. For Children > 12 years old 20 drops die (10 mg die) for 21 days.

intervention.description: Standard dose (400 µg/daily as 100 µg 1 spray nos bid) of nebulized Beclomethasone Dipropionate nasal spray for 21 days.
For Children < 12 years old 10 drops die (5 mg die) for 21 days. For Children > 12 years old 20 drops die (10 mg die) for 21 days.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- children 6-16 years of age with a history of AR in the previous year
- T5SS: ≥5 in the last week before enrollment
Exclusion Criteria:
- asthma symptoms
- acute upper respiratory infections
- anatomic nasal defects (ie, septum deviation), or nasal polyps
- use in the past 4 weeks of nasal or oral corticosteroids, nasal or oral decongestants, antihistamines.
